<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 292]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 99, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 755, 109]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 146, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 724, 134]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 855, 165]]<|/det|>
State the type of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 332, 742, 352]]<|/det|>
The unit square in the \(x\text{-} y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto parallelogram \(OPQR\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 146, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 363, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(a\) and \(b\), the matrix which transforms parallelogram \(OPQR\) onto the unit square.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
It is given that the area of \(OPQR\) is \(2 \mathrm{cm}^2\) and that the line \(x + 3y = 0\) is invariant under the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 144, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 121, 364, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 688, 89]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the List of Formulae (MF19) to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 98, 645, 129]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}(7r + 1)(7r + 8) = a n^{3} + b n^{2} + c n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 532, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 707, 95]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(x^{3} + cx + 1 = 0\), where \(c\) is a constant, has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 106, 551, 125]]<|/det|>
Find a cubic equation whose roots are \(\alpha^{3}, \beta^{3}, \gamma^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 505, 180, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 505, 425, 523]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\alpha^{6} + \beta^{6} + \gamma^{6} = 3 - 2c^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 100, 144, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 693, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the real value of \(c\) for which the matrix \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 & \alpha^3 & \beta^3 \\ \alpha^3 & 1 & \gamma^3 \\ \beta^3 & \gamma^3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\) is singular.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 98, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 435, 89]]<|/det|>
The points \(A, B, C\) have position vectors

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 102, 628, 121]]<|/det|>
\[-\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k},\quad -2\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j},\quad 2\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{k},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 405, 152]]<|/det|>
respectively, relative to the origin \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 164, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 819, 183]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the plane \(ABC\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 164, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 608, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the perpendicular distance from \(O\) to the plane \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 143, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 591, 243]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between the planes \(OAB\) and \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 225, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 636, 91]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for every positive integer \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 92, 695, 128]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2n - 1}}{\mathrm{dx}^{2n - 1}} (x\sin x) = (-1)^{n - 1}\big(x\cos x + (2n - 1)\sin x\big). \quad [7]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[871, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 443, 102]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{x^{2} + x - 1}{x - 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 487, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 918, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 453, 186, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 453, 581, 472]]<|/det|>
Show that there is no point on \(C\) for which \(1 < y < 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 453, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 730, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the intersections of \(C\) with the axes, and sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 918, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 917, 123]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 917, 153]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 175, 917, 193]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 917, 242]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 612, 144, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 605, 534, 636]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{x^{2} + x - 1}{x - 1}\right|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 504, 89]]<|/det|>
Show that the curve with Cartesian equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 98, 599, 121]]<|/det|>
\[(x^{2} + y^{2})^{\frac{5}{2}} = 4xy(x^{2} - y^{2})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 391, 152]]<|/det|>
has polar equation \(r = \sin 4\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 74, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
Using the identity \(\sin 4\theta \equiv 4\sin \theta \cos^3\theta - 4\sin^3\theta \cos \theta\), find the maximum distance of \(C\) from the line \(\theta = \frac{1}{2}\pi\). Give your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 92, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
## Additional Page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
